head.title: Trying Other Ways To Calculate Cab Fares

hedline.hl1: Trying Other Ways To Calculate Cab Fares

abstract.p: Steve Penn letter on Ira Noveck's June 25 letter suggests easier method to split cab fares; drawing (S)

block.p: Here is a method that would solve the problem if any number of riders shared the cab, when no simple formula might be evident.

To do this, consider that the ''true value'' of the trip is the same as if each person took a separate cab, and then prorate the actual cost of the single trip in accord with each rider's proportion of the ''true value.''
Here is a method that would solve the problem if any number of riders shared the cab, when no simple formula might be evident.

To do this, consider that the ''true value'' of the trip is the same as if each person took a separate cab, and then prorate the actual cost of the single trip in accord with each rider's proportion of the ''true value.''
Following Mr. Noveck's example, if the meter reads $10 when the first rider leaves, and $15 when the second leaves, then the true value of the trip is $25 (the sum, as if two cabs had been taken).

The first rider's portion of this is his meter reading divided by the total, 10/25 or 40 percent. So he pays 40 percent of the actual cost of $15, which comes to $6. The second rider's fraction is 15/25 or 60 percent, so his cost is 60 percent of $15, which is $9.
